page.title: 19Stuart House,Liskeard
page.content: This Grade II listed building in the centre of the Conservation Area is thought to date from the early part of the 16th century and to be the work of Sir H.Trecarrel, the architect of Launceston Church(1511-24).During the time of the Civil War,it was owned by the local commissioner,Mr.W.Jean. King Charles stayed there for 6 nights in August 1644 when in pursuit of the Earl of Essex and his parliament forces who had crossed into Cornwall the previous month. Following the defeat of Essex's army in a series of skirmishes around Lostwithiel, Charles once more crossed the Tamar, staying with Mr.W.Jean in Liskeard (Sept.4th)en route.The present name of Stuart House refers to this royal connection. It is hoped to fully restore the house as an Arts and Heritage Centre for the region.
